articles.headline: Uber Attains Eye-Popping New Levels of Funding
articles.snippet: The web-based car ride service raised another $1.2 billion from investors at a $17 billion valuation, attaining a net worth almost unheard-of among start-ups.
articles.abstract: The web-based car ride service raised another $1.2 billion from investors at a $17 billion valuation, attaining a net worth almost unheard-of among start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:40 p.m. | Only a few months ago, Silicon Valley start-ups were celebrated for drawing investors into paying for multibillion-dollar valuations.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Nigerian Television Becomes Front for U.S. in Terrorism Fight
articles.snippet: State Department officials acknowledged that their efforts to directly challenge Boko Haram could prove challenging in a region racked by massacres, bombings and shootings.
articles.abstract: State Department officials acknowledged that their efforts to directly challenge Boko Haram could prove challenging in a region racked by massacres, bombings and shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department is financing a new 24-hour satellite television channel in the turbulent northern region of Nigeria that American officials say is crucial to countering the extremism of radical groups such as Boko Haram. The move signals a ramping up of American counterinsurgency efforts to directly challenge the terrorist group, which abducted nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls in April.

articles.headline: A Risk-Taker’s Game: Insider Trading
articles.snippet: The three subjects of a recent investigation into insider trading are united by at least one quality: They’re all, to varying degrees, gamblers.
articles.abstract: The three subjects of a recent investigation into insider trading are united by at least one quality: They’re all, to varying degrees, gamblers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s probably safe to say that Phil Mickelson didn’t offer a fist bump or a tournament ball, as he often does for fans, when two F.B.I. agents confronted him outside the locker room at Muirfield Village Golf Club in Dublin, Ohio, last month.

articles.headline: Taxi Driver Solidarity
articles.snippet: Facing rising gas prices, stagnant fares and competition from ride-sharing services like UberX, taxi drivers are organizing for better conditions.
articles.abstract: Facing rising gas prices, stagnant fares and competition from ride-sharing services like UberX, taxi drivers are organizing for better conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Never timid in its rush to expand, Uber, the app-based car service, skirted city law when it told drivers in its UberX ride-sharing program last month that they could start picking up passengers at O’Hare International Airport.

articles.headline: P.O.W. Deal Gives Qatar a Victory, and a New Test
articles.snippet: There is much on the line for Qatar, which has wagered its already weakened reputation on keeping the five Taliban militants freed from Guantánamo Bay in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl out of sight and under control.
articles.abstract: There is much on the line for Qatar, which has wagered its already weakened reputation on keeping the five Taliban militants freed from Guantánamo Bay in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl out of sight and under control.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — The five hardened Taliban militants were quickly whisked in a fleet of cars to the shoulder of a highway on the outskirts of the capital just as they arrived. There, out of the public eye and under the watchful gaze of Qatari security, they exchanged warm hugs with a welcome delegation and then once more were whisked off into hiding.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Internet Giants Erect Barriers to Spy Agencies
articles.snippet: Internet companies like Google and Facebook are working to keep governments and their spy agencies out of their servers after revelations that they had been invaded.
articles.abstract: Internet companies like Google and Facebook are working to keep governments and their spy agencies out of their servers after revelations that they had been invaded.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Just down the road from Google’s main campus here, engineers for the company are accelerating what has become the newest arms race in modern technology: They are making it far more difficult — and far more expensive — for the National Security Agency and the intelligence arms of other governments around the world to pierce their systems.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: G.M. Lawyers Hid Fatal Flaw, From Critics and One Another
articles.snippet: The head of the legal department of G.M. was kept in the dark, an internal investigation revealed.
articles.abstract: The head of the legal department of G.M. was kept in the dark, an internal investigation revealed.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — To the legal department at General Motors, secrecy ruled.

articles.headline: A Vow to End Hollow Nods and Salutes
articles.snippet: The chief executive at General Motors, Mary T. Barra, wants to ensure that deadly failures never happen again, but old habits are hard to change.
articles.abstract: The chief executive at General Motors, Mary T. Barra, wants to ensure that deadly failures never happen again, but old habits are hard to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the release last Thursday of the internal report on General Motors’ failure to recall thousands of defective cars for more than a decade, Mary T. Barra, the chief executive, addressed the company’s employees. In her remarks, Ms. Barra projected an earnest and urgent desire to reform the company’s culture, which she said was permeated by “bureaucratic processes that avoided accountability.” That culture meant no one took responsibility for faulty ignition switches in Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars that were ultimately responsible for at least 13 deaths.

articles.headline: Performing Without Net: Stars of YouTube Take to the Stage
articles.snippet: As YouTube personalities grow in popularity and prove more than flashes in the pan, traditional media businesses, particularly concert promoters, are rushing to capitalize.
articles.abstract: As YouTube personalities grow in popularity and prove more than flashes in the pan, traditional media businesses, particularly concert promoters, are rushing to capitalize.
articles.lead_paragraph: A capacity 12,500 tickets were sold. More than 70 performers appeared on three stages. There were 150 security guards, a necessity whenever swarms of shrieking teenage girls assemble. Coke sponsored a live web stream of the festivities.

articles.headline: Affordable Housing That’s Very Costly
articles.snippet: What is known as inclusionary zoning lets developers build more housing units if they charge much lower rents for some of them.
articles.abstract: What is known as inclusionary zoning lets developers build more housing units if they charge much lower rents for some of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abington House, at 500 West 30th Street near the High Line in West Chelsea, is a new luxury residential building and, like a lot of new luxury developments in Manhattan, it’s extremely expensive. The cheapest two-bedroom apartment now listed there rents for $5,850 a month. That gets you only one bathroom; a two-bed, two-bath can run as high as $8,695.

articles.headline: An Elusive Jackpot
articles.snippet: Women have a much harder time becoming a chief executive and hold well under 10 percent of such jobs, but those who do earn the same as men.
articles.abstract: Women have a much harder time becoming a chief executive and hold well under 10 percent of such jobs, but those who do earn the same as men.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you were Marissa Mayer of Yahoo, making nearly $25 million for one year’s worth of work — not to mention getting $50,000 in company-paid personal security — the gender pay gap would probably not be a major concern. Women scaling the heights of corporate America tend to have compensation packages that are as jaw-droppingly gigantic as men at a similar level.

articles.headline: Urged to Multiply, Iranian Couples Are Dubious
articles.snippet: The country’s leadership is offering incentives to begin and enlarge families, but experts say little will change while economic prospects are grim.
articles.abstract: The country’s leadership is offering incentives to begin and enlarge families, but experts say little will change while economic prospects are grim.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In their early 30s, married, and with prospects for successful careers, Bita and Sherag could be contemplating the logical next step in their lives: becoming parents.

articles.headline: Seeing Squalor and Unconcern in a Mississippi Jail
articles.snippet: Two years after control of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility changed hands amid complaints about squalid conditions, advocates for inmates say little has improved.
articles.abstract: Two years after control of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility changed hands amid complaints about squalid conditions, advocates for inmates say little has improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Open fires sometimes burn unheeded in the solitary-confinement units of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, a privately run state prison in Meridian, 90 miles east of here.

articles.headline: Bergdahl Was in Unit Known for Its Troubles
articles.snippet: The issues faced by Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s unit in many ways reflected the problems of the Pentagon’s strategy writ large across Afghanistan at that moment of the war.
articles.abstract: The issues faced by Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s unit in many ways reflected the problems of the Pentagon’s strategy writ large across Afghanistan at that moment of the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: The platoon was, an American military official would assert years later, “raggedy.”
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Outside Money Floods Alaska in Senate Race
articles.snippet: Political ads fill the airwaves in Alaska, which has become a giant receptacle for money from “super PACs” fighting for control of the United States Senate.
articles.abstract: Political ads fill the airwaves in Alaska, which has become a giant receptacle for money from “super PACs” fighting for control of the United States Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — A big part of being an Alaskan is harboring a suspicion of all things Lower 48. It’s an inclination that runs so deep that locals have a proper noun to describe everywhere else — Outside.

articles.headline: As Bowe Bergdahl Heals, Details Emerge of His Captivity
articles.snippet: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl told medical officials he was locked in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, according to officials briefed on his condition.
articles.abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl told medical officials he was locked in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, according to officials briefed on his condition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has told medical officials that his captors locked him in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, and while military doctors say he now is physically able to travel he is not yet emotionally ready for the pressures of reuniting with his family, according to American officials who have been briefed on his condition.

articles.headline: Terrorists Attack Airport in Pakistan, Killing 13
articles.snippet: Ten gunmen infiltrated Karachi international airport, engaging in an extended firefight against security forces, killing 13 people before security forces killed the militants and regained control of the airport.
articles.abstract: Ten gunmen infiltrated Karachi international airport, engaging in an extended firefight against security forces, killing 13 people before security forces killed the militants and regained control of the airport.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — In a ferocious terrorist assault that stretched into Monday morning, suspected Islamist militants infiltrated Pakistan’s largest international airport in Karachi, waging an extended firefight against security forces that resulted in 23 deaths and shook the country’s already fragile sense of security.
articles.byline: By Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Noncompete Clauses Increasingly Pop Up in Array of Jobs
articles.snippet: Once largely limited to the technology and sales sectors, the agreements are entering a range of fields; even camp counselors and hairstylists are being required to sign.
articles.abstract: Once largely limited to the technology and sales sectors, the agreements are entering a range of fields; even camp counselors and hairstylists are being required to sign.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Colette Buser couldn’t understand why a summer camp withdrew its offer for her to work there this year.

articles.headline: Cyberattack Insurance a Challenge for Business
articles.snippet: More businesses are buying policies, but losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.
articles.abstract: More businesses are buying policies, but losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts’s smile is insured. So are Heidi Klum’s legs, Daniel Craig’s body and Jennifer Lopez’s derrière. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Elizabeth A. Harris

articles.headline: In Texarkana, Uninsured and on the Wrong Side of a State Line
articles.snippet: On the Arkansas side of Texarkana, the poor gained access to Medicaid because of the Affordable Care Act. Those across the border in Texas did not.
articles.abstract: On the Arkansas side of Texarkana, the poor gained access to Medicaid because of the Affordable Care Act. Those across the border in Texas did not.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEXARKANA, Tex. — On a hazy, hot evening here, Janice Marks ate a dinner of turkey and stuffing at a homeless shelter filled with plastic cots before crossing a few blocks to the Arkansas side of town to start her night shift restocking the dairy cases at Walmart.

articles.headline: Time Inc. to Set a Lonely Course After a Spinoff
articles.snippet: The magazine publisher, once a towering presence in its industry, faces a shifting market with debts to pay as it begins trading Monday as an independent company.
articles.abstract: The magazine publisher, once a towering presence in its industry, faces a shifting market with debts to pay as it begins trading Monday as an independent company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometime late next year Time Inc., the company that all but created the modern magazine business, will leave its home of more than five decades, the Time & Life Building in Rockefeller Center, and head to new quarters in downtown Manhattan.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Free Music, at Least While It Lasts
articles.snippet: The people who make all that yummy music are actually being loved to death by fans who expect it to be free.
articles.abstract: The people who make all that yummy music are actually being loved to death by fans who expect it to be free.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last Thursday, I stopped at the fruit stand and some big, vivid red grapes caught my eye. The vendor said a two-pound bunch would be $6, which seemed steep. I was about to tell him as much, and then came to my senses and gave him the money.

articles.headline: Japan Seeks to Squelch Its Tiny Cars
articles.snippet: Saying the nation’s automakers are too focused on a niche market, the government has sharply raised taxes on the tiny vehicles, prompting an outcry.
articles.abstract: Saying the nation’s automakers are too focused on a niche market, the government has sharply raised taxes on the tiny vehicles, prompting an outcry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHINSHIRO, Japan — Toshie Yamada’s “kei,” with its pint-size engine and tiny wheels, looks more like a Fisher-Price toy car than a regular truck. But don’t underestimate her Nissan NT 100 Clipper microtruck. At a recent farmers’ market, where she sells orchids from her flower farm here in central Japan, she loaded up a mountain of crates, buckets and a folding table before hopping in and zipping away.

articles.headline: The Well-Followed on Social Media Cash In on Their Influence
articles.snippet: Popular stars of social media platforms like Vine and Instagram are making advertising deals with companies trying to reach their audiences.
articles.abstract: Popular stars of social media platforms like Vine and Instagram are making advertising deals with companies trying to reach their audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good thing social media did not exist during the era of “Mad Men.” It might have put Don and Peggy out of business.

articles.headline: War Gear Flows to Police Departments
articles.snippet: Former tools of combat — M-16 rifles, grenade launchers, silencers and more — are ending up in the armories of local police departments, often with little public notice.
articles.abstract: Former tools of combat — M-16 rifles, grenade launchers, silencers and more — are ending up in the armories of local police departments, often with little public notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEENAH, Wis. — Inside the municipal garage of this small lakefront city, parked next to the hefty orange snowplow, sits an even larger truck, this one painted in desert khaki. Weighing 30 tons and built to withstand land mines, the armored combat vehicle is one of hundreds showing up across the country, in police departments big and small.

articles.headline: Assault on Pakistan Airport Signals Taliban’s Reach and Resilience
articles.snippet: A deadly assault on an airport in Karachi showed how, despite the Pakistani Taliban’s challenges and deepening divisions, their reach has extended into Pakistan’s biggest city.
articles.abstract: A deadly assault on an airport in Karachi showed how, despite the Pakistani Taliban’s challenges and deepening divisions, their reach has extended into Pakistan’s biggest city.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only a week ago, the Pakistani Taliban appeared to be on the ropes. Violent rivalries had split the insurgency in two. Peace talks with the government had collapsed. Military jets had pounded militant hide-outs in the tribal belt.

articles.headline: Merck Bids $3.8 Billion for an Edge in Hepatitis
articles.snippet: Merck will pay $24.50 a share in cash, or about $3.85 billion, for the biotechnology company Idenix in an effort to bolster its arsenal of potential drugs in the hotly competitive hepatitis C area.
articles.abstract: Merck will pay $24.50 a share in cash, or about $3.85 billion, for the biotechnology company Idenix in an effort to bolster its arsenal of potential drugs in the hotly competitive hepatitis C area.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:32 p.m. | Merck will buy the biotechnology company Idenix Pharmaceuticals for $3.85 billion in an effort to bolster its arsenal of potential drugs in the competitive arena of hepatitis C treatments, the companies announced on Monday.
